q2.value: Nathalie Fuss, Carolin Konrad, Sabine Seehagen

q3.value:
Although the effects of mood states on memory have been intensively investigated in adult populations, the effect of internal states such as calm attentiveness or wakeful activity on infant memory functioning has received little attention. 
Numerous studies have demonstrated that adults show improved learning of material which matches their mood while learning (e.g., Bower, 1987; Mayer, McCormick, & Strong, 1995; Ruci, Tomes, & Zelenski, 2009). We will test whether 9-month-old infants show state-congruent learning in a deferred imitation paradigm.

q4.value:
I.	Manipulation check: Infants in the experimental conditions who participate in an animated play period with their caregiver before the demonstration (50% of infants in the congruent state condition and 50% of infants in the incongruent state condition) will show higher a) frequency and intensity of movement (PIM, ZCM; actigraphy) and b) caregiver rating of activity level than Infants in the experimental conditions who participate in a calm play period with their caregiver before the demonstration (50% of infants in the congruent state condition and 50% of infants in the incongruent state condition).    
II.	Infants in both experimental conditions (congruent state, incongruent state) will produce a higher number of target actions at test than infants in the baseline control condition.
III.	Infants in the congruent state condition will produce a higher number of target actions at test than infants in the incongruent state condition.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: There is no additional blinding in this study.

question.value: We have a between subject design with 1 factor (condition) with three levels (same state, different state, baseline control).

q9.value: The infants will be randomly assigned to the two experimental conditions and a baseline control condition as they become available. Specifically, a research assistant will have access to a list containing contact details of parents who have previously expressed interest in taking part in child-development studies. The research assistant will provide caregivers with an explanation of the study. If they decide to participate, the experimenter will alternate between the conditions for the assessments, assigning a condition to an infant prior to their arrival.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Infants must be 9;0 to 10;0 months old, full-term and must not have any serious developmental delays to participate in this study. The research assistant calls the families to ask whether they want to take part in our study and arranges an appointment. Participants will receive € 10 compensation, a little present for the child and a certificate.
After obtaining written informed consent from the caregiver, attachment of an actigraph to the infant’s left ankle, and a warm-up period, infants in the experimental conditions (same state, different state) will receive induction of animated or calm states through animated or calm play with their caregivers for five minutes immediately before a demonstration session where infants will watch a model (the experimenter) perform three target actions with a hand puppet. The demonstration will be either congruent or incongruent with the induced states (e.g., there will be animated or calm sounds accompanying the demonstration). Imitation will be assessed in a test session ten minutes later. At test, infants will be given access to the hand puppet and allowed to freely interact with it for 90s from first touching it. In the congruent state condition, half of the infants will receive a calm play period and calm demonstration and the other half of the infants will receive an animated play period and an animated demonstration. In the incongruent state condition, half of the infants will receive a calm play period and an animated demonstration and the other half of infants will receive an animated play period and a calm demonstration. 
Infants in the baseline control condition will not initially participate in a demonstration session. Half of the infants in this condition will participate in an animated play session and the other half of the infants will participate in a calm play session. Spontaneous production of any target actions will be assessed in a test immediately afterwards. The test is identical to the test experienced by infants in the experimental conditions. 
For further exploratory analyses, infants in the baseline control condition will receive an either animated or calm demonstration immediately after the first test session, which will then be immediately followed by another test session (second test). For half of the infants, the demonstration session will be congruent with the play period (e.g., calm-calm) and for the other half of the infants the demonstration session will be incongruent with the experienced play period (e.g., calm-animated). 
The play periods, demonstration and test sessions are video recorded to review the production of the target actions. Caregivers will rate their infant’s activity level during the play periods.

q13.value: A recent experiment on state-dependent memory (Seehagen, Schneider, Sommer, La Rocca, & Konrad, under revision) revealed a large effect of matching state on 9-month-old infants’ memory. We assume that state-congruency will be reflected in a similar (large) effect size. We will need a final sample of N = 66 infants (i.e., 22 infants per condition) to detect a large effect (power = .8; calculated using GPower, Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007). We anticipate attrition rates of about 10-15%, hence expect having to test about 75 infants in total.

question.value: We will manipulate the infants’ internal state by evoking either calm or animated play with their caregivers for five minutes. The demonstration session will be also be manipulated to be either calm or animated.

•	The outcome variable (dependent variable) will be the number of target actions performed at test (imitation score) for each participant. Infants will receive one point for performing each of the three target actions at test. Hence, the imitation score can vary between 0 and 3. 
•	Effects of state manipulation will be assessed by actigraphy (frequency of movements (zero crossing mode, ZCM) and intensity of movement (proportional integral mode, PIM)) and behavior ratings by caregivers.  For this purpose, caregivers are asked to assess their infants’ state on a scale of 1(very calm) to 10 (very animated) during the play session.

•	To check whether the internal state was successfully manipulated the results of actigraphy (ZCM, PIM) and caregiver behavior rating will be compared between both groups (animated play vs. calm play) using independent t-tests.
•	To confirm that there is no significant difference in the number of target actions between the congruent (animated play period-animated demonstration vs. calm play period –calm demonstration) respectively the incongruent (animated play period-calm demonstration vs. calm play period-animated demonstration) subgroups within the experimental conditions at test independent t-tests will be used. If they are not significantly different, the subgroups can be collapsed resulting in our two experimental groups (state congruent, state incongruent).
•	Likewise we need to check whether there is a significant difference in the number of target actions at test between both subgroups (prior animated play vs. calm play) in the baseline control condition. Again, an independent t-test will be used. In case that they are not significantly different, the subgroups can be collapsed.
•	A one-way ANOVA will be conducted to check whether the three conditions (state congruent, state incongruent, baseline) differ in the number of target actions. Appropriate post-hoc tests will be used if the ANOVA is significant (Bonferroni if variances are equal, Games-Howell if variances are unequal). 
•	If the subgroups differ significantly, they must be treated separately. In this case we will use a one-way ANOVA with five conditions (animated-animated, animated-calm, calm-calm, calm-animated and baseline) or six conditions (animated-animated, animated-calm, calm-calm, calm-animated and baseline animated, baseline calm)

q21.value: We will regard p-values less than .050 as criteria for statistically significant results.

q22.value: Participants will be excluded from final data analysis if they fail to finish the assessment, if there are any crucial technical problems, experimenter errors or interference by caregivers during memory task.

q24.value: We expect that infants also show state-congruent learning in an immediate test. Therefore, we will check whether there is a significant difference in the number of target actions produced in the second test (state congruent vs. state incongruent) in the baseline control condition.

Bower, G. H. (1987). Commentary on mood and memory. Behaviour research and therapy, 25(6), 443-455
Faul, F., Erdfelder, E., Lang, A.-G., & Buchner, A. (2007). G*Power 3: A flexible statistical power analysis program for the social, behavioral, and biomedical sciences. Behavior Research Methods, 39, 175-191.
Mayer, J. D., McCormick, L. J., & Strong, S. E. (1995). Mood-congruent memory and natural mood: New evidence. Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin, 21(7), 736-746.
Ruci, L., Tomes, J. L., & Zelenski, J. M. (2009). Mood-congruent false memories in the DRM paradigm. Cognition and Emotion, 23(6), 1153-1165.
Seehagen, S., Schneider, S., Sommer, K.,  La Rocca, L. & Konrad, C. (under revision). State-dependent memory in infants.

attributes.title: Political Conversations in the American Public

q1.value: Bursting the Bubble: Self-affirmation and Political Discussion Avoidance

q2.value: Lisa Argyle, Elizabeth Anne Jarman, Naomi Hilton, Melanie Freeze, Melanie Freeze

q3.value: Does political disagreement threaten the self, arouse feelings of anxiety, and motivate individuals to avoid political topics in discussions? Can self-affirmation reduce defensive responses to anticipated political disagreement in discussions? Are self and identity-centered psychological determinants of selective avoidance of political discussions independent of social determinants, such as the strength of relationship ties between an ego and alter in a discussion dyad?

q4.value:
In this project we explore an individual's emotional and avoid/approach response to a hypothetical two-person (dyad) discussion. The individual contemplating the discussion is referred to as the ego while the potential discussion partner is referred to as the alter. Conflict-ridden political discussions have the potential to threaten people's need for social harmony, worldview certainty/consistency, and positive self-image. Consequently, anticipating conflict in a political discussions should heighten anxiety and lead the ego to avoid political discussions with the alter.

H1: People will feel more anxious about the idea of bringing up political topics in discussions when disagreement is anticipated compared to when agreement is anticipated because they hope to minimize the psychological and social costs of conflict.

H2: People will avoid political topics in discussions more when disagreement is anticipated compared to when agreement is anticipated because they hope to minimize the psychological and social costs of conflict.

If social considerations are driving the avoidance response, we would expect to see the strength of relationship moderate the amount of anxiety felt and willingness to discuss politics when political disagreement is anticipated. Relationship costs and the threat of political conflict are expected to be greater when pre-existing relationship ties are weaker because there is no existing condition of intimacy and trust in these casual/distant relationships to minimize the social costs of political disagreement.

H3: People are expected to feel more anxiety about the idea of bringing up politics when the discussion alter in the dyad has a casual relationship with the ego compared to a situation where the ego is contemplating a discussion with a significant alter.

H4: People are expected to avoid political conflict more when the discussion alter in the dyad has a casual relationship with the ego compared to a situation where the ego is contemplating a discussion with a significant alter.

While political conflict may threaten relational goals, conflict is also expected to be psychologically threatening. Exposure to views and opinions that are incongruent with a person's worldview may threaten their fundamental need for consistency. Disagreement may also threaten people's need for a positive self-image. According to the self-affirmation theory, defensive responses arise when a person's sense of being ``adaptively and morally adequate'' is compromised. Therefore, Steele (1988) argues the effects of threat to the self-concept can be countered by administering metaphorical booster shots for the ``self-integrity'' (Steele 1988, 262). This is done by giving a people an opportunity to reflect on a personally important value that is unrelated and prior to the threat topic. Individuals who affirm personally important values before exposure to threat are more secure in self-worth and less likely to engage in dissonance reduction strategies. We expect the self-concept reframing produced by self-affirmation will minimize the threat of political conflict and lead people to feel less anxiety about and more open to discussing political topics even when the discussion may threaten their worldview.

H5: Self-affirmation will reduce the amount of anxiety felt about discussing politics under conditions of high ego-threat that is expected to occur when political disagreement is anticipated.

H6: Self-affirmation will reduce avoidance of political topics in conversations under conditions of high ego-threat that is expected to occur when political disagreement is anticipated.

While social and relationship reasons may contribute to an individual's response to anticipated disagreement in a discussion, we do not expect relationship strength to moderate the effect of self-affirmation political conflict avoidance in discussions. Self-affirmation tasks are predicted to reduce ego-defense strategies by manipulating self-concept, not perceptions of social or relationship threat. Incongruent information should be equally threatening to the need for self-consistency and self-enhancement irrespective of the social relation of the source in a discussion. Self-affirmation is predicted to reduce the psychological self-concept discomfort of unwelcome and inconsistent information by securing self-worth and reducing the need to avoid political disagreement. Therefore, we expect the effect of the self-affirmation treatment to be substantively similar when people are considering political discussions with someone who has strong or weak relationship ties with them.

H7: The effects of self-affirmation on anxiety about political discussion are expected to be similar irrespective of strength of relationship ties because affirmation is predicted to manipulate the level of identity/ego-threat, not social threat.

H8: The effects of self-affirmation on political conflict avoidance are expected to be similar irrespective of strength of relationship ties because affirmation is predicted to manipulate the level of identity/ego-threat, not social threat.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

q7.value: There is no other blinding in the study.

question.value:
See the Data, Experimetnal Design, and Measures section "preRegFinal_peerblind.pdf" for full details on the study design.  

To test the effects of anticipated disagreement, self-affirmation, and strength of relationship ties, we will conduct an online experiment in the 2019 Cooperative Congressional Election Study (CCES). The CCES module will be administered by YouGov/Polimetrix in November 2019 and will draw on an internet-based sample of 1,000 U.S. residents constructed from a more than 50,000 opt-in respondents to approximate a random probability sample.

In the online survey, participants are asked to think about a hypothetical scenario and report their level of willingness to bring up a political topic in a discussion (political topic avoidance) and how anxious they would feel if they brought up a political topic (anxiety). We employed a 2X2 factorial experimental design in which the hypothetical scenario is manipulated. Respondents are randomly assigned to a condition that varies ego-alter political conflict (agreement vs. disagreement) and self-affirmation (control vs. self-affirmed). The self-affirmation manipulation: respondents in the treatment group are asked to select from a list of non-political values one that is most important to them and then to write about a time in which it was "especially important to you and made you feel good about yourself." The respondents in the no-affirmation control condition are asked to list everything they have eaten in the last 24 hours.

Because of power limitations, we did not randomize the ego and alter's strength of relationship tie. Instead, all respondents were asked to report their willingness to discuss politics and anxiety about bringing up political topics for "a person who is especially significant in your life" and  "a casual acquaintance." This design structure reduces our ability to clearly assess a between subjects average treatment effect, but still allows us to consider within-subject variance as it relates to the between-subject design. We will be able to explore whether an individual's reaction to anticipated political conflict differs for a casual versus significant alter. In all conditions, respondents were asked to report their topic avoidance and anxiety for the significant person before their responses for the casual acquaintances were assessed.

q9.value: Simple randomization was employed to assign participants to one of the four possible study conditions.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

question.value:
To test the effects of anticipated disagreement, self-affirmation, and strength of relationship ties, we will conduct an online experiment in the 2019 Cooperative Congressional Election Study (CCES). The CCES module will be administered by YouGov/Polimetrix in November 2019 and will draw on an internet-based sample of 1,000 U.S. adult residents constructed from a more than 50,000 opt-in respondents to approximate a random probability sample.

We will conduct a series of difference of means test to ensure respondents participated in the the self-affirmation experimental treatment and control. Robustness checks on subsequent analyses may exclude non-compliant respondents who failed to participate in the writing prompt or if their response was minimal relative to the other responses and further analysis of the content reveals non-compliance in the experimental treatment or control. We will also examine responses prior to the treatment question (systematic missing, etc.) in an attempt to build a second measure of attention that is not directly related to the experimental manipulation and thus less likely to introduce bias.

q14.value: Sample size was determined primarily by the arbitrary budget constraint.

question.value: We manipulate level of self-affirmation and level of political conflict anticipation. See Data, Experimental Design, and Measures section of the attached "preRegFinal_peerblind.pdf" for full details.

registration_responses.q8.question:
See the Data, Experimetnal Design, and Measures section "preRegFinal_peerblind.pdf" for full details on the study design.  

To test the effects of anticipated disagreement, self-affirmation, and strength of relationship ties, we will conduct an online experiment in the 2019 Cooperative Congressional Election Study (CCES). The CCES module will be administered by YouGov/Polimetrix in November 2019 and will draw on an internet-based sample of 1,000 U.S. residents constructed from a more than 50,000 opt-in respondents to approximate a random probability sample.

In the online survey, participants are asked to think about a hypothetical scenario and report their level of willingness to bring up a political topic in a discussion (political topic avoidance) and how anxious they would feel if they brought up a political topic (anxiety). We employed a 2X2 factorial experimental design in which the hypothetical scenario is manipulated. Respondents are randomly assigned to a condition that varies ego-alter political conflict (agreement vs. disagreement) and self-affirmation (control vs. self-affirmed). The self-affirmation manipulation: respondents in the treatment group are asked to select from a list of non-political values one that is most important to them and then to write about a time in which it was "especially important to you and made you feel good about yourself." The respondents in the no-affirmation control condition are asked to list everything they have eaten in the last 24 hours.

Because of power limitations, we did not randomize the ego and alter's strength of relationship tie. Instead, all respondents were asked to report their willingness to discuss politics and anxiety about bringing up political topics for "a person who is especially significant in your life" and  "a casual acquaintance." This design structure reduces our ability to clearly assess a between subjects average treatment effect, but still allows us to consider within-subject variance as it relates to the between-subject design. We will be able to explore whether an individual's reaction to anticipated political conflict differs for a casual versus significant alter. In all conditions, respondents were asked to report their topic avoidance and anxiety for the significant person before their responses for the casual acquaintances were assessed.
registration_responses.q12.question:
To test the effects of anticipated disagreement, self-affirmation, and strength of relationship ties, we will conduct an online experiment in the 2019 Cooperative Congressional Election Study (CCES). The CCES module will be administered by YouGov/Polimetrix in November 2019 and will draw on an internet-based sample of 1,000 U.S. adult residents constructed from a more than 50,000 opt-in respondents to approximate a random probability sample.

We will conduct a series of difference of means test to ensure respondents participated in the the self-affirmation experimental treatment and control. Robustness checks on subsequent analyses may exclude non-compliant respondents who failed to participate in the writing prompt or if their response was minimal relative to the other responses and further analysis of the content reveals non-compliance in the experimental treatment or control. We will also examine responses prior to the treatment question (systematic missing, etc.) in an attempt to build a second measure of attention that is not directly related to the experimental manipulation and thus less likely to introduce bias.

attributes.title: Disgust and Positive Affect
attributes.description: Examining the effect of amusement on disgust responses to video disgust stimuli with trait level disgust sensitivity, threat sensitivity, and fear of contamination as potential moderators.

q1.value: Effects of Amusement on Disgust Responses to Disgust Video Stimuli

q3.value: Limited research has shown that humor or amusement has attenuating effects on disgust reactivity. The aim of the current study is to examine the effects of amusement on disgust responses to video disgust stimuli while considering trait level disgust sensitivity, threat sensitivity, contamination-based obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) symptoms, and behavioral activation as potential moderators.

q4.value:
-Video disgust stimuli with a positive valence (disgust paired with amusement) will elicit lower levels of reported disgust than disgust video stimuli with a negative valence (pure disgust or disgust paired with anger). 
-Disgust sensitivity, threat sensitivity, and contamination-based OCD symptoms will be associated with stronger disgust responses to all video stimuli.
-Disgust sensitivity and contamination fear OCD symptoms will have a moderating effect, such that the attenuating effect of positive valence on negative emotion will be reduced for those will higher levels of disgust sensitivity and contamination-based OCD symptoms.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The study consists of a within-subjects design. Participants first completed questionnaires, which were presented in random order. Participants then completed a word appraisal task, with each item randomized. Participants then proceeded with the video task. All participants first watched a 5 minute neutral video followed by affect ratings for baseline affect. Participants then watched four disgust eliciting videos, presented in random order. All four videos were roughly five minutes longs, and were each followed by affect ratings and a quiz question as an accuracy check.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value: Undergraduate students were recruited for an online study using the Department of Psychological Science's research pool. Participants were compensated with course credit. Accuracy check questions were added to each of the measures included in the online study to account for participant engagement in the study materials. Participants who failed any of the accuracy check questions will be considered unreliable, and thus excluded from all data analyses. The study was hosted by Qualtrics, a secure online survey platform. The Participants first completed several questionnaires, which were presented in random order. Participants then completed a word association task, with each item within the task randomized. Participants then proceeded with a video task. All participants first watched a 5 minute neutral video followed by affect ratings for baseline affect measurement. Participants then watched four disgust eliciting videos—two of which were designed to also elicit amusement—presented in random order. All four videos were roughly five minutes longs, and were each followed by affect ratings and a quiz question as test of participant engagement with the video clips.

q13.value: Our current sample size is 370 prior to implementing exclusion criteria.

q14.value: The goal was to acquire as many participants as possible during a single semester of data collection in order to attain sufficient statistical power for anticipated small effect sizes. Analyses with G-power indicated that a within-person repeated measures ANOVA with a sample of 131 would be powered at .95 to detect small effects.

q15.value: Because our participants were undergraduate students, we terminated data collection at the end of the semester, per departmental policy.

question.value:
Outcome measures:
1.	Disgust responses to each video disgust stimulus were measured via self-report of a scale from 1 (none) to 7 (strong)

2.	Negative affect in response to each video will be measured by taking the mean rating of all negative emotions reported (fear, sadness, distress, guilt, anger, disgust), each reported on a scale from 1 (none) to 7 (strong).

3.	Positive affect n response to each video will be measured by taking the mean rating of all negative emotions reported (Interest, Relief, Enjoyment, Happiness, Amusement, Affection), each reported on a scale from 1 (none) to 7 (strong).

Moderators:
1.	Individual differences in Disgust Sensitivity were measured using the Disgust Scale-Revised (Developed by Haidt, McCauley, & Rozin, 1994, and modified by Olatunji et al., 2007). Items 1 through 14 were rated on a scale from 0 (Strongly disagree) to 4 (strongly agree). Items 15 through 27 were rated on a scale from 0 (Not disgusting at all) to 4 (Extremely Disgusting). Per scoring protocol for this measure, items 1, 6, and 10 were reverse coded, and items 12 and 16 were excluded. A sum score was created by taking the sum of all items with scores that can range from 0 to 100. 
2.	Threat Sensitivity was indexed by combining measures of Neuroticism from the NEO-FFI3, State-Trait Anxiety Inventory, and the Behavioral Inhibition System.
a.	Neuroticism was measured by creating a sum score of NEO-FFI3 items 1, 6,  11, 16, 21, 26, 31, 36, 41, 46, 51, and 56, which were all rated on a scaled from 1 (disagree strongly) to 5 (agree strongly). First, items 1, 16, 31, and 46 were reverse coded
b.	State-Trait Anxiety was measured by creating a sum score of all 20 items, which were reported on a scale from 1 (almost never) to 4 (almost always). 
c.	Behavioral Inhibition System was measured by creating a sum score of items 2, 8, 13, 16, 19, 22, and 24, which were all rated on a scale from 1 (Very true for me) to 4 (very false for me). Items 8, 13, 16, 19, and 24 were reverse coded. 
To combine these three measures, score were converted into z-scores and then a mean was calculated. 
3.	Contamination-Based Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder symptoms were measured using Category 1: Concerns about Germs and Contamination subscale of the Dimensional Obsessive-Compulsive Scale. A sum score was created by summing items 1 through 5, which were reported on a scale from 0 (None at all) to 4 (8 hours or more each day).
4.	Behavioral Activation was measured using the Behavioral Activation System scale of the BIS/BAS (Carver & White, 1994). Items 3, 9, 12, 21, 5, 10, 15, 20, 4, 7, 14, 18 and 23 (all reverse coded) were summed to created create a sum score for BAS.   

Covariates: 
1.	Sex (male or female) will be included as a covariate. Male is coded as 1 and female is coded as 2.

1.	Negative affect in response to each video will be measured by taking the mean rating of all negative emotions reported (fear, sadness, distress, guilt, anger, disgust), each reported on a scale from 1 (none) to 7 (strong).

2.	Positive affect in response to each video will be measured by taking the mean rating of all negative emotions reported (Interest, Relief, Enjoyment, Happiness, Amusement, Affection), each reported on a scale from 1 (none) to 7 (strong).

3.	Threat Sensitivity will be indexed by combining measures of Neuroticism from the NEO-FFI3, State-Trait Anxiety Inventory, and the Behavioral Inhibition System.
a.	Neuroticism will be measured by creating a sum score of NEO-FFI3 items 1, 6,  11, 16, 21, 26, 31, 36, 41, 46, 51, and 56, which were all rated on a scaled from 1 (disagree strongly) to 5 (agree strongly). First, items 1, 16, 31, and 46 will be reverse coded
b.	State-Trait Anxiety will be measured by creating a sum score of all 20 items, which were reported on a scale from 1 (almost never) to 4 (almost always). 
c.	Behavioral Inhibition System will be measured by creating a sum score of items 2, 8, 13, 16, 19, 22, and 24, which were all rated on a scale from 1 (Very true for me) to 4 (very false for me). Items 8, 13, 16, 19, and 24 were reverse coded. 
To combine these three measures, scores will be converted into z-scores and then a mean was calculated.

1.	Bivariate correlations with all variables.
2.	One Repeated Measures Within-Subject ANOVA to test if valence of the video impacts disgust responses. The dependent variable is ratings of disgust in response to each video. The only covariate will be sex.
3.	Four Repeated Measures Within-Subjects ANOVA will be used to test main effects of each of the individual difference variables (1 variable per model) disgust sensitivity, threat sensitivity, Contamination-based OCD symptoms, and behavioral activation. We will also test for moderation within the same model using interaction terms that reflect the interaction of the individual difference variable with video type: disgust sensitivity X video valence; Contamination X video valence; threat sensitivity X video valence; behavioral activation X video valence.  The dependent variable will be reported negative affect in response to each video. The only covariate will be sex.

q22.value: Participants who fail any of the accuracy checks included in each measure will be excluded from all analyses.

q24.value: We will test whether disgust sensitivity, threat sensitivity, and Contamination-Based OCD symptoms are associated with lower levels of positive affect in response to the videos with positive valence. We will also test whether Behavioral activation is associated with higher levels of positive affect in response to the videos with positive valence. Finally, we will explore if any effects for disgust sensitivity and contamination based ocd symptoms hold when we co-vary threat sensitivity

attributes.title: Electrophysiological correlates of precise predictions based on abstract auditory stimulus regularities

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: Electrophysiological correlates of precise predictions based on abstract auditory stimulus regularities

other.value:
The current project is realised in the context of a project course in a master programme in Psychology and therefore needs to be completed within four months. Due to the time constraints arising from that, we have already started data collection. We will, however, not start analysing the data before final sample size (see Question 7) is reached.

EEG data acquisition:
EEG will be recorded at 32 scalp locations according to the 10-20-system and the left and right mastoid positions, EOG will be recorded from four electrodes placed at the outer canthi of each eye and below and above the right eye. Data will be referenced to an electrode placed on the tip of the nose and will be digitised at a sampling rate of 512 Hz.

Additional behavioural task: 
At the end of the experiment, participants will be asked to complete three (oddball) blocks in which they should actively pay attention to the pitch interval within each tone pair and press a button whenever they detect a deviance from the standard interval. Here, d-prime will be analysed as a measure of behavioural performance in terms of sensitivity in the conscious detection of deviants.  

Further analysis: 
We will additionally perform a trend analysis using a quadratic function to test the assumption that deviants that are further away from the expected standard in either direction (i.e. smaller or larger interval) elicit an MMN with a higher amplitude than deviants that are closer to the predicted standard.

sample.value:
Data will be collected from a total of 16 participants. With this sample size, we will be able to detect an effect size of 0.75 in a two-tailed test at the standard .05 alpha error probability with a power of .80.  	

 We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain a power of .95 to detect an effect size that has been reported previously in a comparable experiment at the standard .05 alpha error probability. With regard to the expected effect size, we refer to a study by Paavilainen and colleagues (1999) who also presented participants with tone pairs having a fixed pitch interval between the two tones and analysed MMN in response to deviants with a smaller or larger pitch interval (Paavilainen, Jaramillo, Näätänen, & Winkler, 1999).

Paavilainen, P., Jaramillo, M., Näätänen, R., & Winkler, I. (1999). Neuronal populations in the human brain extracting invariant relationships from acoustic variance. Neuroscience Letters, 265(3), 179–182. https://doi.org/10.1016/S0304-3940(99)00237-2

analyses.value:
Offline, the data will be low- and high-pass filtered with Kaiser-windowed sinc FIR filters at 35 Hz (transition bandwidth: 5 Hz, maximum passband deviation: 0.001) and 0.2 Hz (transition bandwidth: 0.4 Hz, maximum passband deviation: 0.001), respectively. Epochs will be cut from -100 ms to 500 ms relative to the onset of the first tone of a pair and baseline-corrected with respect to the 100-ms interval before the onset of the tone pair. Independent component analysis (ICA) will be used for artefact correction. To improve decomposition, ICA will be computed on a copy of the data that has been pre-processed with a 1 Hz high-pass filter (Kaiser-windowed sinc FIR filter, transition bandwidth: 0.5 Hz, maximum passband deviation: 0.001) and a 35 Hz low-pass filter (Kaiser-windowed sinc FIR filter, transition bandwidth 5 Hz, maximum passband deviation: 0.001) and epoched as described above. Electrodes with bad signal quality and epochs whose maximal peak-to-peak difference exceeds 750 µV will be excluded from the ICA decomposition. To shorten computation time, the data will be down-sampled to 128 Hz before extracting independent components. ICA weights will be transferred to the EEG data pre-processed with the final parameters. Components will be classified using EEGLAB’s ICLabel plug-in (Pion-Tonachini, Kreutz-Delgado, & Makeig, 2019). Components representing clear artefacts of the types  “eye”, “muscle” or “channel noise” with high explained variance will be subtracted from the data. Previously excluded electrodes will be spherically spline interpolated. Epochs still exceeding a 150 µV peak-to-peak difference will be discarded from further analysis. For each subject, the remaining epochs will be used to calculate ERPs separately for all four deviant types (3, 5, 9, 11 semitones interval) from the oddball blocks and the respective four tone pair intervals from the control block.

Mean peak latency will be determined based on latencies of minima in the difference waveforms of each deviant ERP minus the ERP in response to the same tone interval presented in the control block (at equal probability with other deviant and standard intervals), respectively, occurring between 100ms and 300ms relative to the onset of the second tone. 
Note, we will perform the same analysis with the classical procedure to determine MMN, i.e. from the deviant ERP minus standard ERP (for each deviant type separately). 
Before averaging latencies of the identified minima across all deviant conditions, we will make sure that they do not differ significantly between conditions using a one-way repeated-measures ANOVA with the factor “deviant type” (3, 5, 9, 11 semitones interval) on the peak latencies. Mean amplitudes will then be extracted from the difference waveform (deviant ERP - control ERP to the same interval) within a 40ms time window centered around the obtained mean peak latency. 

Extracted mean amplitudes for each deviant condition will subsequently be entered into a two-way repeated measures ANOVA with the factors “direction” (smaller vs. larger than the standard interval) and “magnitude” (two vs. four semitones difference from the standard interval) for statistical evaluation of differences between the conditions.

outliers.value: Participants will be excluded from the analysis if only less than 50 artefact-free epochs remain in any condition after artefact rejection (following the procedures described in Question 5).

dependent.value: The key dependent variable is the mean amplitude of the mismatch negativity (MMN) in the event-related potential (ERP) at electrode Fz and its polarity reversal at mastoid electrode sites (M1, M2) in a 40ms time window centered around the mean MMN peak latency (see Question 5 for further details on how we will determine the mean peak latency and Question 8 for EEG data acquisition parameters).

conditions.value: All participants will be presented with ten oddball blocks and one control block (placed between the oddball blocks at a random position) while they are watching a silent, subtitled movie. Each trial (400 per oddball block and 600 in the control block) will consist of a pair of tones (duration of first tone: 100ms, second tone: 50ms) separated by a silent interval of 40ms between the two tones. In the oddball blocks, four types of deviants (with a probability of 3%, respectively) will occur within the auditory sequence: pitch intervals between the first and the second tone of a pair might either be two or four semitones larger or smaller than the interval in standard trials in which the second tone is always seven semitones higher in pitch than the first tone. Thus deviant intervals are either three, five, nine or eleven semitones. In the control block, all four deviant intervals as well as the standard interval are presented at equal probability, i.e. 20%, respectively.

hypothesis.value: We hypothesize that predictions of future sensory events formed automatically during auditory perception are precise in nature and that the magnitude of electrophysiological responses to violations of these internal expectations is modulated by the size of the difference between predicted and actual sensory input. Specifically, this assumption will be tested in a paradigm in which participants do not have an internal physical template of upcoming auditory input established during earlier presentations of the same stimulus (i.e. the next stimulus cannot be directly inferred from what is held in sensory memory) but need to proactively apply an abstract rule in order to make predictions.

registration_responses.analyses:
Offline, the data will be low- and high-pass filtered with Kaiser-windowed sinc FIR filters at 35 Hz (transition bandwidth: 5 Hz, maximum passband deviation: 0.001) and 0.2 Hz (transition bandwidth: 0.4 Hz, maximum passband deviation: 0.001), respectively. Epochs will be cut from -100 ms to 500 ms relative to the onset of the first tone of a pair and baseline-corrected with respect to the 100-ms interval before the onset of the tone pair. Independent component analysis (ICA) will be used for artefact correction. To improve decomposition, ICA will be computed on a copy of the data that has been pre-processed with a 1 Hz high-pass filter (Kaiser-windowed sinc FIR filter, transition bandwidth: 0.5 Hz, maximum passband deviation: 0.001) and a 35 Hz low-pass filter (Kaiser-windowed sinc FIR filter, transition bandwidth 5 Hz, maximum passband deviation: 0.001) and epoched as described above. Electrodes with bad signal quality and epochs whose maximal peak-to-peak difference exceeds 750 µV will be excluded from the ICA decomposition. To shorten computation time, the data will be down-sampled to 128 Hz before extracting independent components. ICA weights will be transferred to the EEG data pre-processed with the final parameters. Components will be classified using EEGLAB’s ICLabel plug-in (Pion-Tonachini, Kreutz-Delgado, & Makeig, 2019). Components representing clear artefacts of the types  “eye”, “muscle” or “channel noise” with high explained variance will be subtracted from the data. Previously excluded electrodes will be spherically spline interpolated. Epochs still exceeding a 150 µV peak-to-peak difference will be discarded from further analysis. For each subject, the remaining epochs will be used to calculate ERPs separately for all four deviant types (3, 5, 9, 11 semitones interval) from the oddball blocks and the respective four tone pair intervals from the control block.

Mean peak latency will be determined based on latencies of minima in the difference waveforms of each deviant ERP minus the ERP in response to the same tone interval presented in the control block (at equal probability with other deviant and standard intervals), respectively, occurring between 100ms and 300ms relative to the onset of the second tone. 
Note, we will perform the same analysis with the classical procedure to determine MMN, i.e. from the deviant ERP minus standard ERP (for each deviant type separately). 
Before averaging latencies of the identified minima across all deviant conditions, we will make sure that they do not differ significantly between conditions using a one-way repeated-measures ANOVA with the factor “deviant type” (3, 5, 9, 11 semitones interval) on the peak latencies. Mean amplitudes will then be extracted from the difference waveform (deviant ERP - control ERP to the same interval) within a 40ms time window centered around the obtained mean peak latency. 

Extracted mean amplitudes for each deviant condition will subsequently be entered into a two-way repeated measures ANOVA with the factors “direction” (smaller vs. larger than the standard interval) and “magnitude” (two vs. four semitones difference from the standard interval) for statistical evaluation of differences between the conditions.
registration_responses.outliers: Participants will be excluded from the analysis if only less than 50 artefact-free epochs remain in any condition after artefact rejection (following the procedures described in Question 5).
registration_responses.dependent: The key dependent variable is the mean amplitude of the mismatch negativity (MMN) in the event-related potential (ERP) at electrode Fz and its polarity reversal at mastoid electrode sites (M1, M2) in a 40ms time window centered around the mean MMN peak latency (see Question 5 for further details on how we will determine the mean peak latency and Question 8 for EEG data acquisition parameters).
registration_responses.conditions: All participants will be presented with ten oddball blocks and one control block (placed between the oddball blocks at a random position) while they are watching a silent, subtitled movie. Each trial (400 per oddball block and 600 in the control block) will consist of a pair of tones (duration of first tone: 100ms, second tone: 50ms) separated by a silent interval of 40ms between the two tones. In the oddball blocks, four types of deviants (with a probability of 3%, respectively) will occur within the auditory sequence: pitch intervals between the first and the second tone of a pair might either be two or four semitones larger or smaller than the interval in standard trials in which the second tone is always seven semitones higher in pitch than the first tone. Thus deviant intervals are either three, five, nine or eleven semitones. In the control block, all four deviant intervals as well as the standard interval are presented at equal probability, i.e. 20%, respectively.
registration_responses.hypothesis: We hypothesize that predictions of future sensory events formed automatically during auditory perception are precise in nature and that the magnitude of electrophysiological responses to violations of these internal expectations is modulated by the size of the difference between predicted and actual sensory input. Specifically, this assumption will be tested in a paradigm in which participants do not have an internal physical template of upcoming auditory input established during earlier presentations of the same stimulus (i.e. the next stimulus cannot be directly inferred from what is held in sensory memory) but need to proactively apply an abstract rule in order to make predictions.

attributes.title: Facial Electromyography while viewing Painful Expressions in Own- and Other-Race Faces

q1.value: Facial Electromyography while viewing Painful Expressions in Own- and Other-Race Faces

q2.value: Taylor Popp, Peter Mende-Siedlecki, Philip Gable

q3.value: Past research suggests that there is racial bias in the perception of painful faces such that individuals are better able to identify pain in own- versus other-race faces. The present study seeks to determine whether facial mimicry plays a role in this relationship. We investigate whether individuals exhibit more facial mimicry in response to own- versus other-race painful expressions.

q4.value:
Corrugator, orbicularis oculi, and mentalis activity will increase in response to painful faces. 

Moreover, pain intensity will interact with target race to shape EMG activity: we predict that higher degrees of pain expressed by the target will be associated with greater corrugator, orbicularis oculi, and mentalis activity, and this relationship will be particularly pronounced for own-race (e.g., White) faces. Separate analyses will be conducted for each of these EMG measures. 

EMG activity are predicted to relate to scores of intergroup contact and dehumanization such that having less interaction with, or more explicitly negative views toward the outgroup will result in less facial mimicry. 

We also predict a main effect of target race on behavioral responses during the task—specifically, participants will see pain less readily on Black (vs. White) faces. 

Moreover, we predict a relationship between racial bias in pain perception and differences in EMG activity. We’ll assess this relationship both overall at each site, and separately within each cluster—and we predict this relationship will be strongest within the ambiguous cluster.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: The present study is a repeated-measures design. Participants will view Black and White faces depicting expressions of pain. Each of eight blocks will contain four target faces (2 Black, 2 White) depicting 11 levels of pain each for a total of 44 pain ratings per block. The 11 levels of pain will be divided into three clusters: low (1, 2, 3, 4), ambiguous (5, 6, 7, 8), and high (9, 10, 11). This yields a 2 (race: Black vs. White) x 3 (degree of pain: low vs. ambiguous vs. high) within-subjects design.

q9.value: All participants will see all pain levels of all target faces exactly one time. Both independent variables (race and degree of pain) are completely within-subjects. Each of eight blocks contains all 11 levels of pain for four target faces (two Black, two White). Faces are shown in a randomized order within blocks and blocks are shown in a randomized order.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: Data was collected during the Fall 2019 semester. However, EMG data were only visible in its raw form at the time of data collection, and pain ratings from participants were not visible to the researchers. EMG data have been filtered and cleaned of artifacts, but have not been analyzed.

question.value: Data will be collected at the University of Alabama, and will recruit from the psychology subject pool (e.g., participants are Introduction to Psychology (PY 100, 105) students participating for research credit). Participants must be 18-years-old, have 20/20 vision or wear glasses/contacts, and be right-handed. Data will be collected for one semester.

q13.value: The final sample size of the study will include all participants who completed the study during the Fall 2019 semester and met all inclusion criteria without meeting exclusion criteria.

q14.value: Participants will be recruited throughout the total lifespan of the psychology subject pool for the Fall 2019 semester. Data collection will be terminated once the subject pool closes at the end of the semester.

q15.value: Data collection will be terminated once the University of Alabama Psychology Subject Pool closes for the Fall 2019 semester.

question.value: The race (Black or White) of each target face will be manipulated. Race is entirely within-subject and orthogonal. The degree of pain (low, ambiguous, or high) of each target face will also be manipulated. Degree of pain is entirely within-subject and orthogonal.

Dependent variable 1: EMG activity
(1)	EMG recordings based on a pair of electrodes placed on the right corrugator muscle
(2)	EMG recordings based on a pair of electrodes placed on the right orbicularis oculi muscle
(3)	EMG recordings based on a pair of electrodes placed on the right mentalis muscle

Dependent variable 2: Thresholds for visual perception of painful expressions
(1)	Calculated separately within each race/load cell as the point-of-subjective equality for recognizing pain. Pain ratings will be linearly transformed to a scale from 0 to 1 (0 = not in pain, 1 = in pain), and separately fit with a cumulative normal function to calculate the PSE in each cell of the 2 (race) × 2 (load) design. The PSE represents the point at which a target would be equally likely to be judged as being in pain or not being in pain. (Task and analytic approach adapted from Looser & Wheatley, 2010 and Hackel et al., 2014.)

Third variables: 
(1)	Feeling thermometers representing participants’ “uniquely human” and “human nature” dehumanization (Haslam et al., 2006) and intergroup contact (adapted from Cloutier et al., 2014)

The pain ratings for faces in a low degree of pain will be calculated as an average of all pain ratings for faces in the low levels of pain (levels 1, 2, 3, and 4). The pain ratings for faces in an ambiguous degree of pain will be calculated as an average of all pain ratings for faces in medium levels of pain (levels 5, 6, 7, and 8). The pain ratings for faces in a high degree of pain will be calculated as an average of all pain ratings for faces in high levels of pain (levels 9, 10, and 11).

We predict an interaction between race (Black vs. White) and degree of pain (low vs. ambiguous vs. high): higher degrees of pain expressed by the target will be associated with greater corrugator activity, and this relationship will be particularly pronounced for own-race faces. This prediction will be assessed in a 2x3 ANOVA assessing the effects of race and degree of pain experienced by target face. We predict an interaction between race (Black vs. White) and degree of pain (low vs. ambiguous vs. high): higher degrees of pain expressed by the target will be associated with greater orbicularis oculi activity, and this relationship will be particularly pronounced for own-race faces. This prediction will be assessed in a 2x3 ANOVA assessing the effects of race and degree of pain experienced by target face. We predict an interaction between race (Black vs. White) and degree of pain (low vs. ambiguous vs. high): higher degrees of pain expressed by the target will be associated with greater mentalis activity, and this relationship will be particularly pronounced for own-race faces. This prediction will be assessed in a 2x3 ANOVA assessing the effects of race and degree of pain experienced by target face. We predict a main effect of race, such that participants will see pain less readily on Black (vs. White) faces overall. This prediction will be assessed in a repeated measures ANOVA assessing the main effect of race on pain perception. Positive correlation between racial bias in pain perception and race-based gaps in EMG activity. This prediction will be assessed first in terms of a zero-order correlation, and then in a within-subjects mediation analysis. We will assess this relationship overall at each recording site, and then separately within the low, ambiguous, and high clusters. We predict that this relationship will be strongest within the ambiguous cluster.

q20.value: Our dependent variable, thresholds for visual perception of pain expressions, will be calculated separately within each race/load cell as the point-of-subjective equality for recognizing pain. Pain ratings will be linearly transformed to a scale from 0 to 1 (0 = not in pain, 1 = in pain), and separately fit with a cumulative normal function to calculate the PSE in each cell of the 2 (race) × 2 (load) design. The PSE represents the point at which a target would be equally likely to be judged as being in pain or not being in pain. (Task and analytic approach adapted from Looser & Wheatley, 2010 and Hackel et al., 2014.)

q21.value: Predicted analyses will use p values (less than .05, one tailed), and confidence intervals (do not contain zero) to determine significance.

q22.value: Data will be excluded for the following reasons: a) Non-differentiation of responses (e.g., the same response on 90% of trials or greater) will result in exclusion from all analyses b) Participants whose EMG data fall more than three standard deviations from the mean will be excluded from all analyses concerning the facial region data as an outlier. If data from a participant is only an outlier at one facial region, data from other facial regions will not be excluded. c) Participants with fewer than 30 EMG epochs per condition will be exclude from analyses. d) Participants with excessive EMG artifact (based on visual inspection of data) will be excluded. e) Participants not compliant with experimental procedures will be excluded. f) If participants are aware of the manipulation (i.e., they note that some of the faces are identical aside from skin color), all of their data will be removed from analyses. g) For the current hypotheses, only data from White participants will be analyzed. However, data from Black participants will also be analyzed in an exploratory fashion. Participants will also be excluded based on an exclusion rule established by Hackel et al. (2014): we will average participants’ responses for morph 1 and morph 11 for each target group, subtract the former from the latter, and if the resultant is less than 1, the participant will be excluded from analysis.

q23.value: Incomplete or missing data will be omitted if the participant does not complete at least 4 of the 8 blocks. If the participant is only missing data for individual difference measures, then that participant's data from the pain ratings and treatment task will be used in relevant analyses. However, that participant's data will not be included in analyses pertaining to the individual difference measures. If data is lost for only one facial region, data for the other two regions will be kept for relevant analyses. However, data will be omitted from analyses pertaining to the facial region that the participant is missing.

registration_responses.q12.question: Data will be collected at the University of Alabama, and will recruit from the psychology subject pool (e.g., participants are Introduction to Psychology (PY 100, 105) students participating for research credit). Participants must be 18-years-old, have 20/20 vision or wear glasses/contacts, and be right-handed. Data will be collected for one semester.
registration_responses.q16.question: The race (Black or White) of each target face will be manipulated. Race is entirely within-subject and orthogonal. The degree of pain (low, ambiguous, or high) of each target face will also be manipulated. Degree of pain is entirely within-subject and orthogonal.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Dependent variable 1: EMG activity
(1)	EMG recordings based on a pair of electrodes placed on the right corrugator muscle
(2)	EMG recordings based on a pair of electrodes placed on the right orbicularis oculi muscle
(3)	EMG recordings based on a pair of electrodes placed on the right mentalis muscle

Dependent variable 2: Thresholds for visual perception of painful expressions
(1)	Calculated separately within each race/load cell as the point-of-subjective equality for recognizing pain. Pain ratings will be linearly transformed to a scale from 0 to 1 (0 = not in pain, 1 = in pain), and separately fit with a cumulative normal function to calculate the PSE in each cell of the 2 (race) × 2 (load) design. The PSE represents the point at which a target would be equally likely to be judged as being in pain or not being in pain. (Task and analytic approach adapted from Looser & Wheatley, 2010 and Hackel et al., 2014.)

Third variables: 
(1)	Feeling thermometers representing participants’ “uniquely human” and “human nature” dehumanization (Haslam et al., 2006) and intergroup contact (adapted from Cloutier et al., 2014)
registration_responses.q18.question: The pain ratings for faces in a low degree of pain will be calculated as an average of all pain ratings for faces in the low levels of pain (levels 1, 2, 3, and 4). The pain ratings for faces in an ambiguous degree of pain will be calculated as an average of all pain ratings for faces in medium levels of pain (levels 5, 6, 7, and 8). The pain ratings for faces in a high degree of pain will be calculated as an average of all pain ratings for faces in high levels of pain (levels 9, 10, and 11).
registration_responses.q19.question: We predict an interaction between race (Black vs. White) and degree of pain (low vs. ambiguous vs. high): higher degrees of pain expressed by the target will be associated with greater corrugator activity, and this relationship will be particularly pronounced for own-race faces. This prediction will be assessed in a 2x3 ANOVA assessing the effects of race and degree of pain experienced by target face. We predict an interaction between race (Black vs. White) and degree of pain (low vs. ambiguous vs. high): higher degrees of pain expressed by the target will be associated with greater orbicularis oculi activity, and this relationship will be particularly pronounced for own-race faces. This prediction will be assessed in a 2x3 ANOVA assessing the effects of race and degree of pain experienced by target face. We predict an interaction between race (Black vs. White) and degree of pain (low vs. ambiguous vs. high): higher degrees of pain expressed by the target will be associated with greater mentalis activity, and this relationship will be particularly pronounced for own-race faces. This prediction will be assessed in a 2x3 ANOVA assessing the effects of race and degree of pain experienced by target face. We predict a main effect of race, such that participants will see pain less readily on Black (vs. White) faces overall. This prediction will be assessed in a repeated measures ANOVA assessing the main effect of race on pain perception. Positive correlation between racial bias in pain perception and race-based gaps in EMG activity. This prediction will be assessed first in terms of a zero-order correlation, and then in a within-subjects mediation analysis. We will assess this relationship overall at each recording site, and then separately within the low, ambiguous, and high clusters. We predict that this relationship will be strongest within the ambiguous cluster.

q1.value: Online study on the relationship between faces' aesthetic traits and perceived trustworthiness

q3.value:
In this study, we aim to verify the extent to which individuals' aesthetic traits affect the level of perceived trustworthiness in viewers. Moreover, we want to verify the extent to which the relationship is affected by participants' gender (same or different from viewed face), ethnicity  (same or different from viewed face - ingroup / outgroup), or viewed face's age (child or adult).
Therefore, we will measure the level of perceived aesthetic judgment ("How much do you like this person?") and trust ("How much do you trust this person?") of individuals exposed to faces of different ages, sex, and ethnicity.

q4.value: We expect to find a positive relationship between the level of perceived aesthetic  ("How much do you like this person?")  and perceived trust  ("How much do you trust this person?").

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Participants will be shown N = 64 faces of human adults (N = 32) and children (N=32), randomly selected from the ffhq-dataset, so that faces within each group are balanced for gender (male and female) and ethnicity (Caucasian vs Asian). Faces will be presented in random order alongside with two 100-points scale questions: "How much do you like this person?" and "How much do you trust this person". Each participants will give ratings to all the 64 faces.

q9.value: Images will be presented in randomized order to the participants (N. possibilities = 64!)

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants' will be recruited trough online advertisement on different Social Media. No compensation will be given.

q13.value: N = 330 participants. No subdivision in groups n will be performed during data collection.

q14.value: Assuming 6 groups (same age/ different age, ingroup/outgroup and same-sex/ opposite sex), a weak effect size (cohen’s d)*= 0.1, alpha = 0.05 and power = 0.95. To perform an analysis of variance we will require ~ 330 participants. Effect size in previous studies was found to be medium, here it’s corrected to take into account the presence of a positive bias in psychological research.

q15.value: We will stop once 330 participants are recruited.

question.value:
We will measure the perceived level of aesthetic pleasure and trustworthiness on a 0-100 scale. 
We will measures' participants age, gender, and ethnicity as covariates.  Effects of participants' gender and ethnicity will be tested in relationship with presented faces sex, ethnicity, and age to see any possible effect
Pearson correlation coefficient will be used to test the association between the two collected measures.

q20.value: We plan to normalize the data for each participants' scores, in order to have a full scale 0-100 or 0-1 for each participant.

q21.value: Results of the Pearson’s correlation coefficient will be used to verify the direction and strength of the association between the two variables, while its 2-tailed p-value will be used to verify the significance of the association.

q24.value: To verify the role of participants' gender and ethnicity, a three-way ANOVA (pearson r ~ Image_Age * Ingroup/Outgroup * SameSex/DifferentSex) will be performed on pearson's r evaluated for each subgroup and participants  (for each participants, 8 pearson's r score will be computed, one for each possible interaction).

attributes.title: The inﬂuence of task difﬁculty on mind wandering and thought constraint

q1.value: The inﬂuence of task difﬁculty on mind wandering and thought constraint (replication)

q3.value:
This study is a direct replication of "The inﬂuence of task difﬁculty on mind wandering and thought constraint". We found that the relative frequency of freely-moving versus non-freely moving thought decreased when task-difficulty increased (one-sided t-test, p < .05) in both on- and off-task thoughts. The purpose of this study is to confirm this result with a larger sample.

Background:


Mind wandering,from a family-resemblances perspective,is a multi-dimensional phenomenon best described as a natural category with graded membership. Three dimensions of prototypicality have been proposed: intentionality, task relatedness, and the most recent addition, constraint (also known as the freely-moving thoughts dimension). In the current study, we examined whether changes in task difﬁculty would inﬂuence the rate of constrained versus unconstrained thoughts. Prior work has shown that mind wandering varies with task-difﬁculty and has been interpreted as resulting from either an executive resource trade-off or a failure in executive control. Here, we examine the influence of task difficulty on the thought constraint dimension of mind wandering.


In a prior experiment we showed increases in freely-moving thoughts in an easy versus difficult task. We however, did not measure task-relatedness and it is possible that the change in rates of freely-moving thoughts merely reflects changes in task-unrelated thoughts.

Here, we manipulated task difﬁculty via working memory load using an n-back task (e.g., Baird et al., 2012; Konishi, McLaren, Engen, & Smallwood, 2015; Smallwood et al., 2011). Participants viewed a series of numbers indicating whetheratargetwasevenorodd. In the“easy”group,participants would indicate whether the currently presented number was even or odd (0-back) and in the “hard” task, participants had to indicate whether the number presented two trials ago was even or odd (2-back). Periodically throughout the task we asked participants to indicate whether their thoughts were currently freely-moving or not. Finally, O’Neill et al. (2019) suggested that the constraint dimension might, in some way, be related to the concept of a “ﬂow state” (Csikszentmihalyi, 1988; Nakamura & Csikszentmihalyi, 2014) or “deep effortless concentration” (Marty-Dugas & Smilek, 2019). We therefore, included a brief survey at the end of the experiment to determine whether rates of unconstrained thoughts correspond with reports of effortless concentration or “ﬂow”.

q4.value: We hypothesized that the relative amount of freely-moving versus non-freely moving thoughts will be higher in the easy versus the difficult task for both on- and off-task thought.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: 2 x 2 mixed design with difficulty (easy vs hard) as the between-subjects factor and task-relatedness as the within-subjects factor.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: 300 participants (150 per group) will be recruited through Amazon Mechanical Turk. Participants will be paid $2.50 for completing the experiment (~20 minutes). Participants who do not complete all portions of the experiment will be excluded.
Task difficulty (easy versus hard) will be manipulated using the 0-back and 2-back tasks

- reaction time and accuracy performance in the n-back tasks
- rates of freely-moving thoughts
- rates of task-related/unrelated thoughts
- flow questionnaire responses
- demographics
- wordsum performance

- ANOVA 
- Ex-gaussian analysis of reaction times
- signal detection analysis for n-back performance

attributes.title: Background
attributes.description: Materials used to prepare study including hypothesis and predictions.

q1.value: The potential link between exculpation and stigmatization in Tourette Syndrome: a vignette study

q3.value:
Please refer to the protocol contained in materials.

Over-all research questions addressed:

Baseline study: Does viewing Tourettic behavior as neurological lead to both exculpation ​and​ social exclusion?

Disclosure study: Does epigenetic reframing of Tourettic behavior allow to find a better optimum between these components of stigma?

q4.value:
For detailed predictions please refer to the protocol contained in materials.

Baseline study: viewing Tourettic behavior as more neurological leads both to less attribution of blame and more social distance/isolation.

Disclosure study: epigenetic reframing in neurological condition leads to less social distance & social isolation whilst blame remains constant; epigenetic reframing in psychological condition leads to less blame whilst social distance & social isolation remain constant.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q7.value: The study is an on-line Qualtrics survey with fully anonymized participation. It will be rolled out via the Prolific service towards adult native English speakers in the age range 18-35 (in order to keep familiarity with classroom settings).

question.value:
Mixed design (for details, please refer to protocol document in materials):

For initial step: Spearman correlation between ‘Perceived Etiology’ (Biology-Psychology) and ‘Attribution of Blame’ (Likert 1/No-5/Yes): required sample size 115.

For neurological vs psychological condition: Mann-Whitney U tests on variables:

-​ ​Attribution of blame (1-5 Likert)
-​ ​Social Distance Scale (scale)
-​ ​Social isolation Question (1-5 Likert)
-​ ​Independent variable: group Bio or Psycho
Required sample size 92 in each group so 184 in total.

q9.value: Randomization between psychological and neurological conditions will be done via Qualtrics randomizer (see survey flow).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
The Prolific service will be used to recruit participants & Quatrics service will be used to collect data. 

Power estimation indicates the need for 184 participants to cover the hypotheses. We decided to use 220 participants to take into account non-consent and partial responses (and to cover a possible exclusion of people diagnosed with Tourette or another diagnosis of mental 'disorder' or people directly acquainted with them given previous research shows their responses will be significantly different from those in the general public - see demographics part of survey). We also decided to restrict the age range from 18-35 to keep familiarity with classroom settings.

q15.value: We will distribute to a fixed group of 220 participants. When non-consent, partial or exclusion (see above) are unexpectedly high we will redistribute to more participants until we reach the power analysis requirement.

question.value: See protocol document in materials.
See protocol document in materials.
See protocol document in materials.
We will use the test implied by the power analysis as recorded in the protocol document.

q21.value: We will use the test implied by the power analysis as recorded in the protocol document.

q22.value: We will not exclude any data except for non-consent or partial responses and for the exclusion criterium of diagnosis of mental 'disorder' or direct acquaintance with people diagnosed with a mental 'disorder' as mentioned higher.

q24.value:
Within subject evolution of dependent variables.

Between subject differences of blame attribution/social distance & isolation of 'epigenetic' and 'label disclosure' steps. 

Correlation between demographics as collected and responses.

We also ask some open text feedback from participants which we won't disclose but that could inspire interpretation of data or tuning towards further studies.
